awd_titl_txt: Conference: Third US School and Workshop on Theory and Applications of TDDFT
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded by contributions from Condensed Matter and Materials Theory program of the Division of Materials Research and the Chemical Theory, Models, and Computational Methods program of the Division of Chemistry. 

This award supports participation of students in the Third US School and Workshop on Theory and Applications of Time-Dependent Density Functional Theory (TDDFT), which will take place at Rutgers University-Newark from June 29, 2023 to July 8, 2023. TDDFT is an efficient and formally exact way of describing the dynamics of interacting many-body systems, and has become the method of choice for calculating excitation energies and optical properties of complex molecules and a broad range of materials. The school, which will be held during the first week, will involve the participation of 35 students and 8 instructors. Students will learn the fundamentals of TDDFT via theory lectures and gain hands-on experience by learning to use state-of-the-art TDDFT codes. The workshop to be held during the second week will involve invited presentations on cutting edge developments and applications of TDDFT from some of the leaders in the field as well as junior scientists. The conference will allow students to learn about the foundations and applications of TDDFT from experts in the field, facilitate the exchange of ideas between junior and senior researchers, and serve as an opportunity for creating new collaborations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to organize the third School and Workshop on Theory and Applications of Time-Dependent Density-Functional Theory, from June 29 through July 8, 2023 at Rutgers University-Newark, USA. The organizers were Christine Isborn (University of California-Merced), Neepa Maitra (Rutgers University-Newark, Michele Pavanello (Rutgers University-Newark), Carsten Ullrich (University of Missouri), and Adam Wasserman (Purdue University).

Time-dependent density-functional theory (TDDFT) provides an efficient, elegant, and formally exact way of describing the dynamics of interacting many-body quantum systems. Today, TDDFT has become the method of choice for calculating excitation energies of complex molecules, and for describing optical and spectroscopic properties of a broad range of materials. The main intellectual merit of this conference was that it covered the latest state of the art in TDDFT and, by bringing together students and experts in Chemistry, Physics and Materials Science, fostered discussions to define and analyze important problems to advance the field. The broader impact of this school and workshop was to train a new and diverse generation of scientists in the formal and practical/computational elements of TDDFT, and to include a large number of early career invited speakers together with prominent established researchers known for their communication and mentoring effectiveness. In the selection of the invited participants and students, much consideration was given to gender and underrepresented groups.

The 2023 TDDFT Summer School was a great success. Thanks to NSF support, 55 students were able to attend the 5 days of the summer school, followed by the 4 days of the workshop.  The school was intended for early career researchers who wanted to gain understanding of how to simulate time-dependent quantum dynamics and charge transfer phenomena with DFT and TDDFT. Morning theory lectures and afternoon hands-on lectures covered fundamentals of DFT and TDDFT.  The following 4-day workshop showcased cutting-edge multidisciplinary research in DFT and TDDFT and featured 38 speakers. There were poster sessions both in the school and in the workshop, where each of the students presented their research.
